intro: Perotis perrottetii, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a herbaceous perennial native to Mexico and the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its vibrant orange to red ray flowers and dark green, heart-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 2 to 4 feet and thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is well adapted to arid and semi-arid climates, making it a popular choice for drought-tolerant landscaping. Its flowers bloom from summer to fall, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
